definitions: hold or grip something tightly with your hand or fingers
engage or disengage a mechanical coupling device that connects or disconnects power transmission
perform successfully in a crucial or high-pressure situation when success is most needed
examples: She clutched the railing tightly as the boat rocked
The child clutched his mother's hand in the crowd
Press the clutch pedal before shifting gears in the car
The clutch mechanism failed and needed immediate repair
He always clutches in the final moments of important games
The team's star player clutched when they needed him most

definitions: fill or cover a space with too many objects in a disorganized way
fill someone's mind or a situation with too much confusing or unnecessary information
examples: Old magazines and papers clutter every surface in the room
Don't clutter your desk with unnecessary items today
Too many details clutter the main argument of your presentation
Irrelevant thoughts cluttered her mind during the important meeting

definitions: train and instruct athletes or sports teams to improve their performance and skills
help someone develop specific skills or abilities through guidance and instruction
travel from one place to another by means of a large passenger bus
examples: She coaches the university basketball team every weekday afternoon
He coached Olympic swimmers for over twenty successful years
The manager coaches new employees in customer service techniques
A professional coach helped him improve his public speaking
We decided to coach across the country instead of flying
They coached from London to Edinburgh for the weekend

definitions: provide or supply a furnace, engine, or heating system with coal as fuel
take on or load coal as fuel for a steam engine or ship
examples: Workers coal the massive furnaces at the steel mill daily
The old steam locomotive needs someone to coal it regularly
The ship coaled at the port before continuing its journey
Steam trains would coal every few hundred miles during travel

definitions: combine or merge separate elements or groups into a single unified whole or mass
come together and unite to form one body, group, or organization
examples: The various protest groups coalesced into a powerful political movement
Oil droplets coalesce when they come into contact with each other
Opposition parties coalesced around the common goal of electoral reform
Different communities coalesced to address the environmental crisis together

definitions: move forward using momentum without applying power or making active effort
proceed or advance with little effort or difficulty through a situation
travel along or near the edge of a coastline or shore
examples: The car coasted down the hill with the engine turned off
After pedaling hard, she coasted on her bicycle for several blocks
He coasted through his final semester with minimal study effort
The company coasted on its reputation without making real improvements
The ship coasted along the Mediterranean shore for three days
We coasted past beautiful cliffs and secluded beaches yesterday

definitions: cover something completely with a layer of another substance or material
apply a protective or decorative coating to a surface using paint, varnish, or similar substance
examples: Snow coated the entire landscape during the overnight storm
Dust had coated every surface in the abandoned house
Workers coat the metal parts with anti-rust treatment before assembly
She coated the cake with rich chocolate frosting this afternoon

definitions: persuade someone to do something through gentle encouragement, patience, or flattery rather than force
obtain or achieve something through patient and gentle persuasion or encouragement
examples: She coaxed her shy daughter to join the other children
The teacher coaxed the reluctant student to participate in class
He coaxed a smile from the upset child with jokes
The mechanic coaxed better performance from the old engine

definitions: pave a road or path with cobblestones or similar rounded stones
put something together quickly and somewhat crudely using whatever materials or resources are available
examples: Workers cobbled the old town square with traditional stone blocks
The historic street was cobbled over two centuries ago
She cobbled together a meal from leftovers in the refrigerator
The team cobbled a solution from spare parts and determination

definitions: tilt or turn something to one side at an angle
pull back the hammer or mechanism of a firearm in preparation for firing
raise something, especially a body part, in an alert or attentive position
examples: He cocked his head to one side to listen more carefully
The dog cocked its head curiously at the strange sound
The soldier cocked his rifle before entering the dangerous area
She cocked the pistol with a distinct clicking sound
The bird cocked its tail feathers in a display of aggression
He cocked his eyebrow in skeptical response to her explanation

definitions: wrap or enclose something completely in a protective covering or environment
isolate oneself from external influences or the outside world for protection or development
examples: The caterpillar will cocoon itself in silk before transforming completely
She cocooned the fragile artifact in layers of protective material
After the trauma, he cocooned himself in his apartment for months
The family cocooned themselves from negative media coverage during the crisis

definitions: write instructions for a computer program using a programming language
convert information or messages into a system of symbols, letters, or numbers
assign a specific code or classification number to something for identification or organization
examples: She codes web applications using JavaScript and Python programming languages
The developer coded the entire mobile app in just six weeks
Military personnel code all sensitive messages before transmission to headquarters
The spy coded his report using a secret cipher
Hospitals code patient records according to standard medical classification systems
The librarian coded each new book with its proper catalog number

definitions: arrange or organize laws, rules, or principles into a systematic and comprehensive code or system
collect and arrange existing laws into an organized legal code or formal system
examples: The committee worked to codify the organization's ethical guidelines into policy
Scholars attempted to codify the principles of effective leadership this year
The government plans to codify all existing environmental regulations next year
Legal experts codified centuries of common law into statutory form

definitions: force someone to do something against their will using threats, pressure, or intimidation
obtain something from someone by using force, threats, or other forms of pressure
examples: The dictator coerced citizens into supporting his oppressive political regime
She refused to be coerced into signing the unfavorable contract
Criminals coerced money from local businesses through threats of violence
The interrogator coerced a false confession from the innocent suspect

definitions: exist at the same time or in the same place without conflict
live together peacefully despite having different beliefs, values, or characteristics
examples: Different species coexist successfully in this diverse ecosystem every season
Traditional and modern architecture coexist harmoniously in the old city
Various religious groups coexist peacefully in this tolerant multicultural community
The former enemies learned to coexist after decades of conflict

definitions: wind or twist something into a series of loops or a spiral shape
move in a winding or curved path like a spiral or series of loops
examples: The sailor coiled the rope neatly on the deck after use
She coiled her long hair into an elegant bun this morning
The snake coiled around the tree branch to rest in shade
Smoke coiled upward from the campfire into the evening sky

definitions: invent or create a new word, phrase, or expression that becomes part of language
manufacture metal money or currency by stamping or molding precious metals
examples: Shakespeare coined many words and phrases that we still use today
The scientist coined a new term to describe her groundbreaking discovery
The mint coins thousands of new pennies and quarters every day
Ancient civilizations coined money from gold and silver for trade

definitions: happen at exactly the same time as something else by chance or design
occupy the same position in space or have the same location
correspond exactly or agree completely in nature, character, or timing
examples: Her birthday coincides with the national holiday every few years
The solar eclipse will coincide with the full moon tomorrow night
The two roads coincide for several miles through the mountain pass
The borders of the two countries coincide along this river
Our opinions coincide perfectly on most political and social issues
The research findings coincide with earlier studies from different institutions

definitions: work together with others on a joint project or shared goal using combined efforts
cooperate with an enemy or occupying force, especially during wartime, often considered treasonous
examples: Scientists from different countries collaborate on climate research projects regularly
The two companies decided to collaborate on developing new sustainable technology
Some citizens collaborated with the occupying army during the war
The resistance fighters targeted those who collaborated with enemy forces

definitions: fall down or cave in suddenly due to loss of structural support or strength
fail completely and suddenly, especially referring to systems, organizations, or health conditions
fold or compress something into a much smaller or more compact form
examples: The old building collapsed during the earthquake without any warning
The bridge collapsed under the weight of heavy traffic this morning
The stock market collapsed after the announcement of the financial scandal
His health collapsed from years of stress and poor lifestyle choices
She collapsed the tent and packed it away in minutes
The folding chair collapses for easy storage and transport

definitions: catch, seize, or detain someone, especially to question or arrest them
put a collar around the neck of an animal for identification or control
examples: Police collared the suspect after a brief chase through downtown
The reporter collared the politician for an impromptu interview outside
The veterinarian collared the stray dog before taking it to shelter
Farmers collar their cattle with identification tags for tracking purposes

definitions: bring or gather things together from various sources or locations into one place
acquire and accumulate items of a particular type as a hobby or interest
receive or obtain money that is owed as payment or debt
examples: The volunteers collect donations for the local food bank every weekend
She collected her belongings and prepared to leave the office
He collects vintage stamps from countries around the world as hobby
The museum collects rare artifacts from ancient civilizations for display
The landlord collects rent from tenants on the first day monthly
The charity collected over ten thousand dollars during the fundraising campaign

definitions: crash into something or someone with violent force while moving
come into strong disagreement or conflict with opposing ideas, interests, or people
examples: The two cars collided at the intersection during rush hour
The asteroid could collide with Earth in several million years
Traditional values collide with modern lifestyle choices in many families
The senator's opinions collided with those of his own political party

definitions: establish a colony in a territory by settling there with a group of people
settle in and establish control over a territory or area for political or economic purposes
examples: European powers colonised vast territories across Africa and Asia for centuries
The company plans to colonise Mars within the next several decades
Pioneers colonised the western territories during the nineteenth century expansion
Bacteria can colonise the human digestive system and cause serious infections

definitions: establish a colony in a territory by settling there with a group of people
settle in and establish control over a territory or area for political or economic purposes
examples: European powers colonized vast territories across Africa and Asia for centuries
The company plans to colonize Mars within the next several decades
Pioneers colonized the western territories during the nineteenth century expansion
Bacteria can colonize the human digestive system and cause serious infections

definitions: add color to something by applying paint, dye, or other coloring substances
influence or affect someone's perception, judgment, or understanding of a situation
examples: Children love to color pictures in their books with crayons
The sunset colored the entire sky in brilliant shades of orange
Personal experiences color our interpretation of events around us daily
His political bias colored his analysis of the election results

definitions: add color to something by applying paint, dye, or other coloring substances
influence or affect someone's perception, judgment, or understanding of a situation
examples: Children love to colour pictures in their books with crayons
The sunset coloured the entire sky in brilliant shades of orange
Personal experiences colour our interpretation of events around us daily
His political bias coloured his analysis of the election results

definitions: arrange, style, or untangle hair using a comb or similar tool
search through something very thoroughly and systematically to find specific information or objects
examples: She combs her daughter's hair every morning before school begins
The stylist combed his hair into a fashionable new style
Detectives combed the crime scene for clues and evidence carefully
Researchers combed through thousands of documents to find the missing data

definitions: fight against an enemy or opponent using weapons or physical force
take active measures to oppose, reduce, or eliminate something harmful or undesirable
examples: Soldiers combat enemy forces on the battlefield with advanced weapons
The martial artist trained daily to combat skilled opponents effectively
The government launched programs to combat poverty and unemployment nationwide
Doctors combat the disease with new treatments and preventive measures

definitions: join or merge two or more things together to form a single unit
unite different people, groups, or organizations to work together toward a common goal
examples: The recipe combines chocolate and vanilla flavors in perfect harmony
Scientists combine different chemicals to create new compounds and materials
The two companies decided to combine their resources for the project
Opposition parties combined forces to challenge the ruling government effectively

definitions: move toward the speaker or a specified place from another location
arrive at a particular place or destination after traveling there
happen, occur, or take place at a specific time or in sequence
become available, accessible, or ready for use or consumption
examples: Please come here and help me with this heavy box
The children come running when they hear the ice cream truck
We came to the city by train early this morning
The guests will come to the party around seven tonight
Spring comes after the long cold winter months every year
The moment of truth finally came during the championship game
The new model will come in three different colors next month
Fresh vegetables come from the local farmers market on Saturdays

definitions: provide emotional support, consolation, or reassurance to someone who is upset or distressed
make someone feel physically comfortable by providing suitable conditions, furniture, or amenities
examples: The mother comforted her crying child with gentle words and hugs
Friends came to comfort the family during their time of grief
Soft pillows and blankets comfort guests in the luxury hotel rooms
The ergonomic chair was designed to comfort people during long work

definitions: give an authoritative order or instruction that must be obeyed by subordinates
have authority or control over people, resources, or situations in a leadership position
deserve and receive something such as respect, attention, or a high price because of merit
examples: The general commanded his troops to advance toward the enemy position
The teacher commanded the students to sit down and be quiet
She commands a team of fifty engineers at the technology company
The captain commands the entire ship and all its crew members
The painting commands a very high price at international art auctions
His expertise and experience command respect from colleagues and competitors alike

definitions: honor the memory of someone or something with a special ceremony, monument, or observance
serve as a memorial or reminder of an important person, event, or achievement
examples: The nation commemorates its independence with parades and fireworks every year
The museum commemorated the victims with a moving memorial service
This statue commemorates the brave soldiers who died in battle
The annual festival commemorates the founding of the historic city

definitions: begin or start something in a formal or official manner with proper ceremony
start legal proceedings, academic activities, or other formal processes according to established procedures
examples: The graduation ceremony will commence at ten o'clock this morning
Construction work on the new bridge will commence next month
The university will commence fall classes on the first Monday
Legal proceedings commenced immediately after filing the formal complaint today

definitions: praise someone formally and officially for their achievements, behavior, or service to others
entrust someone or something to the care, protection, or consideration of another person
examples: The principal commended the students for their outstanding academic achievements this year
The committee commended her dedication to community service and volunteer work
I commend my family to your care while I travel abroad
The dying man commended his soul to God in prayer

definitions: make remarks, observations, or statements about something, expressing an opinion or reaction
provide explanatory notes, annotations, or additional information about a text, situation, or event
examples: The teacher commented on each student's performance during the presentation
Viewers commented enthusiastically about the television show on social media
The editor commented extensively on the manuscript with detailed suggestions
Scholars commented on the ancient text to help modern readers understand

definitions: develop and market something, especially a product or idea, to make it commercially profitable
exploit something, particularly cultural or artistic work, primarily for financial gain rather than inherent value
examples: The company plans to commercialize the new technology within two years
Scientists work with industry partners to commercialize their research discoveries
Critics argue that television commercialized professional sports beyond recognition today
The festival organizers commercialized the traditional celebration to attract more tourists

definitions: formally authorize or order the creation of something, especially an artistic work or construction project
give someone official authority or power to perform a specific role or duty
put a ship, building, or piece of equipment into active service or operation
examples: The museum commissioned a famous artist to create a sculpture
The city commissioned a study on traffic patterns and congestion problems
The president commissioned her as ambassador to the European Union
The military commissioned him as an officer after graduation
The navy will commission the new aircraft carrier next summer
The power plant was commissioned after extensive safety testing procedures

definitions: perform or carry out an act, especially a crime, error, or wrongdoing
pledge or devote oneself, time, resources, or energy to a particular cause, activity, or relationship
send someone to a prison, hospital, or other institution for treatment or punishment
examples: The suspect committed several burglaries in the neighborhood last month
Students often commit errors when they rush through their homework
She committed herself to studying medicine for the next eight years
The company committed significant resources to environmental protection and sustainability programs
The judge committed the defendant to prison for five years
The family committed their elderly relative to a specialized care facility

definitions: communicate in a very intimate, spiritual, or deep emotional way with someone or something
live together in a small community where people share resources, responsibilities, and often beliefs
examples: She felt she could commune with nature during her meditation
The spiritual leader taught followers how to commune with higher powers
The hippies decided to commune together on the rural farm
Several families commune in the intentional community outside the city

definitions: exchange information, ideas, or feelings with someone through speaking, writing, or other means
convey or express thoughts, feelings, or information clearly and effectively to others
be connected or have a passage between two places or rooms
examples: Parents need to communicate openly with their children about important topics
The team members communicate regularly through email and video conferences
Good teachers communicate complex ideas in ways students can easily understand
Artists communicate emotions and experiences through their creative works and expressions
The two rooms communicate through a door in the connecting wall
These hiking trails communicate with the main pathway near the summit

definitions: travel regularly between home and work or school over a considerable distance
reduce a legal punishment, especially a death sentence, to a less severe penalty
exchange or substitute one thing for another, typically something less severe or demanding
examples: She commutes fifty miles each way to work in the city
Many people commute by train to avoid traffic congestion during rush
The governor commuted the prisoner's death sentence to life imprisonment today
The judge commuted his jail time to community service instead
The insurance company commuted his monthly payments to a single lump sum
Medieval serfs could commute their labor obligations by paying money

definitions: press or squeeze something together to make it smaller, denser, or more tightly packed
make a formal agreement, treaty, or contract between parties, especially governments or organizations
examples: The machine compacts recyclable materials into dense bales for easier transport
Snow becomes compacted under the weight of footsteps and vehicles
The two nations compacted to establish peaceful trade relations permanently
The neighboring states compacted regarding water rights and usage policies

definitions: accompany someone as a friend, partner, or associate, especially on a journey or activity
provide company and friendship to someone who might otherwise be alone or isolated
examples: The guide dog companions the blind woman wherever she travels
A trusted friend companioned him throughout his difficult recovery period
Professional caregivers companion elderly people who live alone in the community
The volunteer companions children in the hospital during their treatment

definitions: accompany or go along with someone, providing companionship during an activity or journey
associate or spend time with particular people, especially in social situations or relationships
examples: She companied her grandmother to the doctor's appointment this morning
The bodyguard companied the celebrity throughout the entire public event
He companies with intellectuals and artists in his social circle
She prefers to company with people who share her interests

definitions: examine two or more things to identify similarities, differences, and relative qualities or characteristics
liken one thing to another by pointing out similarities or making an analogy
examples: The students compare different historical periods in their research papers
Consumers compare prices and features before making major purchase decisions
Critics often compare her poetry to that of famous classical writers
The coach compared the team's performance to a well-oiled machine

definitions: show deep sympathy, concern, and care for someone who is suffering or in distress
grant special leave from work or military duty due to family emergency or crisis
examples: The nurse compassionated with patients and families during their difficult times
Religious leaders compassionated with the community after the natural disaster
The military compassionated him so he could care for his dying mother
The company compassionated several employees during the family health crisis

definitions: force someone to do something against their will using authority, pressure, or circumstances
evoke a strong feeling or response that someone cannot resist or ignore
examples: Financial difficulties compelled him to sell his house and move
The law compels all citizens to pay taxes on their income
Her moving speech compelled the audience to donate generously to charity
The evidence compelled the jury to reach a unanimous guilty verdict

definitions: pay someone money as reimbursement for loss, damage, or injury they have suffered
make up for something undesirable by providing something good or beneficial in return
counteract or offset the effects of something by providing an opposite or balancing force
examples: The insurance company will compensate victims for their property damage losses
The company compensated workers who lost their jobs during the restructuring
Her kindness compensates for her lack of technical skills in management
The restaurant's excellent service compensates for the somewhat high menu prices
Special lenses compensate for vision problems caused by eye muscle weakness
The pilot compensated for strong winds by adjusting the flight path
